articles.title: Hypothesis for a single mean
articles.description: Introduction to hypothesis test for a single mean.
articles.contents:
Hypothesis test
Basically, a hypothesis test is a statistical method to test a claim, believes or a status quo. In this page we are interest in the
hypothesis test for a single mean, such that we are interested in one sample.
Formulate the hypothesis test
In hypothesis test, a researcher needs to formulating two competing hypotheses, the null hypothesis (\(H_0\)) and the alternative hypothesis
(\(H_a\)). After that, he/she needs to use a statistical evidence to evaluate which hypothesis is more likely.
Population statndard deviation is known
If the population standard deviation is known (\(\sigma\)), or we have a large sample size, then we can use the normal (\(Z\)-Statistics).
\[Z _\textit{test} = (\bar{x} - μ) / (σ / √n)\]
Where:
\(z\) is the z-statistic
\(\bar{x}\) is the sample mean
\(μ\) is the population mean
\(σ\) is the population standard deviation
\(n\) is the sample size

Contents

Mixture Vine Copula

Mixture R-Vine Copula.
COVID-19 and Copula

Squential Truncation.

MI and turncation R-vine copoula.
Novel pruning and truncating of the mixture of vine copula clustering models:
Novel mixture Truncaion.

articles.title: Sample and Population
articles.description: A simple introduction to sample and population.
articles.contents:
Population
Population refers to the entire set of items or objectives that are of interest to a specific study, such as a group of people,
animals, and objectives.
Studying the population is a complex task, often challenging and impractical. One reason for that is the size of the
population. In many real-life cases, the population size is vast, making it time-consuming and challenging to access and collect the required data
from each member of the population.
Sample
Sample is a part (or a subset) of the population.
Sample is collected from the population under the study to make inferences about the entire population.
Due to sample variability, there will always be a potential for sample error.
Sample error refers to the difference between the population and the sample taken from it.
Sample techniques
Sampling techniques can be divided into statistical and non-statistical methods.
Non-statistical Sampling method
Convenience sampling:
It is a non-probability sampling technique.
The researchers selected the individuals based on their availability and willingness to participate.
It is easy and cost-effective in comparison to other sampling techniques.
Due to the lack of random selection, it may lead to selection bias.
Judgment sampling:
It is a non-probability sampling technique.
It is based on the researchers’ judgment and experiences.
It is cost-effective as the researchers focus on specific groups in this sampling method.
This method may lead to potential bias as it is based on the researcher’s judgment, and hence, the selected individuals may influenced by the researcher’s bias or pre-conceptions.
Statistical Sampling method
Simple random sample:
In simple random sampling, each person/item/subject has an equally likely chance to be selected.
Coming Soon!
